title: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg Commemorations Begin in Washington
summary: President Trump plans to announce Saturday a nominee to succeed the groundbreaking jurist. WASHINGTON-Official commemorations of the late Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg began at the Supreme Court on Wednesday, honoring the groundbreaking jurist whose death reverberated across the country and touched off an intense political clash.

title: U.S. Coronavirus Cases Rise by Nearly 40,000
summary: With Covid-19 deaths mounting in the country, vaccine regulators face politics. The U.S. reported nearly 40,000 new coronavirus cases, a day after passing 200,000 deaths, with new infections trending upward for the past week.

title: Acting DHS Chief's Confirmation Hearing Brings Pointed Questioning
summary: Chad Wolf faced questions about DHS handling of coronavirus pandemic, civil unrest and a whistleblower complaint. Chad Wolf, who has overseen the Department of Homeland Security in an acting role since late last year, faced sharp questions at his Senate confirmation hearing Wednesday about the department's handling of the coronavirus pandemic, civil unrest around the country and allegations that employees were politically pressured to modify intelligence assessments.

title: Trudeau Pivots From Scandal With Rebuild of Canadian Economy
summary: Liberal government outlines agenda to address widening social gaps and other effects of pandemic. OTTAWA-Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau laid out his plans to rebuild the country's economy, in an effort to address damage done by the coronavirus pandemic and turn the page on a scandal over the awarding of a contract.

title: Good Vaccine Progress, Bad Politics
summary: A fourth candidate enters Phase 3, never mind the carpers.. Johnson & Johnson announced Wednesday that its vaccine candidate for Covid-19 will enter Phase 3 trials, the fourth to do so. The speed of vaccine development is remarkable, and credit goes to scientific advances and some smart government decisions.

title: Justice for Breonna Taylor
summary: Kentucky's Attorney General argues for truth over narratives.. At a time when Americans have watched too many public officials abdicate their responsibilities to uphold the law, Kentucky Attorney General Daniel Cameron on Wednesday proved to be an encouraging exception.

title: Hunter Biden's Business
summary: A Senate report reveals Joe's passivity amid his son's influence-peddling.. Joe Biden is running against Donald Trump's character and supposed corruption, so a Senate report documenting the Biden family's ethical swampiness certainly counts as news.

title: Stakeholders vs. Shareholders
summary: A new SEC rule raises the bar for corporate proxy proposals.. Progressives are trying to hijack corporate proxy voting to impose their political agenda on business decisions. Credit the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for looking out for the 99.99% of shareholders.

title: Brooklyn Redevelopment Proposal Withdrawn After Local Backlash
summary: Industry City developers pull plans that would have allowed for additional types of retail and classroom space. Industry City developers withdrew their application to rezone the Brooklyn property, prompting cheers from local elected officials and neighborhood groups who said the proposal would exacerbate unaffordability and gentrification in the working-class neighborhood.

title: California to Ban Sales of New Gas-Powered Cars Starting in 2035
summary: Governor says widespread adoption of zero-emission vehicles will reduce greenhouse-gas emissions and help to combat climate change. California Gov. Gavin Newsom signed an order Wednesday that aims to end the sale of new gasoline and diesel-powered passenger cars in the state by 2035.

title: No Need to Sweat Covid Vaccination Rates
summary: As long as seniors and essential workers are immunized, deaths will drop and life can resume.. President Trump has said he hopes the federal government can begin distributing a Covid-19 vaccine in October. Many in the public-health community are skeptical, arguing instead for a more controlled, and likely slower, release. The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine have recommended heavy-handed government rationing during the initial rollout. Science magazine reports that only half the U.S. population may eventually want the vaccine, a level too low to achieve herd immunity. Some in the media and the public-health community are arguing that all this necessitates continued restrictions on economic activity.

title: A Triumph for Peace Is a Humiliation for the 'Peace Industry'
summary: John Kerry said it couldn't be done, but Arab leaders are embracing normal relations with Israel.. The Abraham Accords, signed by Israel, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates, represent an immense victory for peace in the Middle East and a major defeat for the peace industry. Composed of liberal think tanks and nongovernmental organizations, virtually all of academia and the media, and a cadre of former officials, commentators and philanthropists, that industry had long insisted that Arab-Israeli peace couldn't be achieved without Israeli territorial concessions, a freeze on settlement building, and the creation of a Palestinian state. "There will be no advance and separate peace with the Arab world without . . . Palestinian peace," Secretary of State John Kerry told the Brookings Institution in 2016. "That is a hard reality."

title: Here We Go Again: Debates Start Tuesday
summary: Trump and Biden continue the tradition JFK and Nixon began six decades ago.. On Tuesday night, President Trump and former Vice President Joe Biden will arrive on the health-education campus of Case Western Reserve University and the Cleveland Clinic to begin the first presidential debate of the general election. This "Clash in Cleveland" will have its own tempo and tone, but the 36 such debates since 1960 have elements in common.

title: Biden Can't Duck Trump's Court
summary: A Barrett or Lagoa nomination will give voters a choice about the Court's role.. No other personal story about Ruth Bader Ginsburg has been told more this week than the one about her warm relationship with conservative Justice Antonin Scalia. It brings to mind similar stories of the "Friends after 6 p.m." camaraderie between Ronald Reagan and Democratic House Speaker Tip O'Neill. Thanks for the memories, but those days are gone.

title: 'Law & Leviathan' Review: Self-Government Minus the Self
summary: Two Harvard professors-one from the left, the other from the right-defend the 'morality' of the administrative state.. The U.S. Constitution's separation of powers is a concession to man's fallibility. Man tends to abuse power, so the Founders dispersed it. To preserve liberty and promote the public interest requires not just intentions but also institutions.

title: Procter & Gamble Calls for Change to Annual TV Ad-Buying Process
summary: P&G brand chief Marc Pritchard says TV networks use information about client budget forecasts for an advantage in negotiations. Procter & Gamble Co.'s top marketing executive called for changes to the annual TV upfront process during the Association of National Advertisers Media and Measurement Conference, criticizing a decades-old method of buying TV ads as antiquated and inefficient.

summary: 'Sen. Murkowski said Tuesday she could not rule out that she would vote to confirm a Trump nominee if the Judiciary Committee approves one before the November election.'. From a Sept. 22 Alaska Public Media report:

title: Enterprise Tech Efforts Move Beyond Survival Mode
summary: No longer scrambling with quick fixes to address remote work, more companies are making deeper, more strategic investments in tech, say vendors. Enterprise technology firms say companies are emerging from survival mode and kick-starting pre-Covid-19 efforts to overhaul their operations with digital tools.

title: TikTok Asks Judge to Halt Trump's Download Ban
summary: Video-sharing app argues proposed ban violates constitutional provisions for free speech, due process. WASHINGTON-TikTok Inc. asked a federal judge to stop the Trump administration from imposing a ban on the popular video-sharing app over national-security concerns.

title: WeWork Sells Majority Stake in China Business, Cutting Costs
summary: Group led by investment firm Trustbridge Partners paid $200 million to increase stake in WeWork China. WeWork is selling control of its China business, the latest sign that the company is abandoning its former rapid growth approach and looking to reduce risk.

title: Harvard Business School Pledges to Tackle Race Issues
summary: Dean says school will revise curriculum, recruit more Black students. Harvard Business School said Wednesday it would boost its enrollment of Black students in future classes, hire a chief diversity officer and build more issues of race and diversity into its case-study method of teaching.

title: Violence Plagues Afghanistan as Peace Talks With Taliban Struggle to Take Off
summary: The bloodshed complicates the first-ever direct negotiations taking place between the two parties in Qatar. KABUL-Deadly violence in Afghanistan has marred the first-ever direct talks between Kabul and the Taliban, underscoring the high stakes that face the warring sides as they struggle to get negotiations off the ground to end nearly two decades of fighting.

title: SEC Raises Bar for Shareholder Resolutions
summary: Critics say move could chill corporate democracy; companies cite costs caused by gadfly investors. WASHINGTON-The Securities and Exchange Commission raised the bar for investors to submit proposals for a vote at companies' annual meetings, a win for executives who have bristled at shareholder efforts to influence corporate policies on social and political issues.

title: Pandemic Tips New York City's Martinique Hotel Into Bankruptcy
summary: Operator of landmark hotel at 32nd Street and Broadway hopes to restructure collective-bargaining agreement. The operator of New York City's historic Martinique hotel, one of Manhattan's oldest, filed for chapter 11 protection, hoping for relief from rent payments and union obligations as the Covid-19 pandemic hammers the Big Apple's lodging market.

title: JPMorgan Nears Deal to Settle Spoofing Probes
summary: Authorities target illicit practice of submitting misleading orders to exchanges. JPMorgan Chase & Co. is nearing an agreement with federal prosecutors and regulators to pay a fine to settle civil and criminal charges that its traders rigged futures and securities markets, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Secrets of Wealthy Women Podcast Listeners: Share Your Thoughts
summary: Although the show is coming to an end, we are more committed than ever to telling stories about women, money and power.. When we started the WSJ's Secrets of Wealthy Women podcast about three years ago, we aimed to showcase the stories of some of the smartest and most accomplished women in the world.

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Her Replacement
summary: The level of disunity in our society has reached epic proportions for modern times and could very well be close to a breaking point.. Regarding your editorial "Breaking Judicial Norms: A History" (Sept. 21): While I agree with the historical record that it is the Democratic Party which has challenged or ignored historical precedent when it got in the way of achieving or enhancing political power, that is only part of the current calculation. It looks like a certainty that if Joe Biden wins and the Democrats take the Senate they will abolish the filibuster and pack the Supreme Court, regardless of whether Ruth Bader Ginsburg's seat is filled by the current Senate or not. But the issue for me is less the nomination than the current state of the nation.

title: Pompeo Warns About Chinese Influence in Wisconsin Visit
summary: Chief U.S. diplomat, appearing in a battleground state, says his purpose is foreign policy, not politics. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo used a statehouse speech in Wisconsin on Wednesday to warn about the dangers of Chinese political influence in the U.S.

title: What Evidence Is There of Big Tech's Harm?
summary: As we are aware, no one has demonstrated that consumers have been harmed by the dominance of American tech companies.. In "Breaking Up or Better Regulating Big Tech?" (Letters, Sept. 21), Rep. Ken Buck calls the analysis in our article "The Misguided Antitrust Attack on Big Tech" (op-ed, Sept. 15) "simplistic and flawed" and claims that "the bipartisan instigator" of congressional antitrust concern is "that big tech companies are using their market dominance to strangle competition at the expense of the American consumer." The purpose of our article was to show the massive consumer benefits coming from the rise of American big tech companies. If Congress has evidence that consumers are being harmed, it should present it. To this point, as far as we are aware, no one has demonstrated that consumers have been harmed by the dominance of American tech companies.

title: Joe Biden's Proposed Spending Comes With a High Cost
summary: Until Congress gets spending under control, any proposals for vast new government programs should be dismissed as dangerous and immoral seductions.. Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden continues to trot out new spending proposals that are not only hopelessly unrealistic but also disturbingly reckless ("Biden Pitches Highest Spending in Decades," U.S. News, Sept. 15). Government spending already is well out of control and has been for some time. Even if Congress halted all the coronavirus emergency spending immediately, the previous underlying trends would persist and federal deficits and debt would continue swelling. It is just a matter of time before the potentially catastrophic consequences of this profligacy arise.

U.S. stocks fell sharply Wednesday, extending their turbulent run as hopes for additional fiscal stimulus dimmed, coronavirus cases rose and investors continued to question the valuations of tech stocks.

title: Nikola's Talks With Energy Firms Stalled Following Short-Seller Report
summary: Pause in electric-truck maker's discussions with BP, others over hydrogen refueling stations marks strategic setback amid heightened scrutiny. Talks between electric-truck maker Nikola Corp. and several potential partners, including BP PLC, to build hydrogen-refueling stations stalled following allegations the company had misled investors, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: University of California Accepted Less Qualified Students With Connections, Audit Says
summary: Applicants with money or ties to decision-makers were admitted at four campuses over more accomplished candidates. The University of California system accepted dozens of applicants with connections to donors and employees over better qualified candidates between 2013 and 2018, the state's auditor said Tuesday. The Berkeley, Los Angeles, Santa Barbara and San Diego campuses admitted 64 students who had money or ties to decision makers, but who were rated lower by admissions readers than rejected applicants, the audit found. The majority of the students accepted were white and at least half came from families with average annual incomes of $150,000 or more.

title: New York's MTA Wants to Borrow Up to $2.9 Billion From Federal Reserve
summary: Operator of New York City's subway system had hoped for a federal coronavirus bailout, but the relief package has stalled in Congress. New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to apply to the Federal Reserve to borrow as much as $2.9 billion from a short-term lending program, as it faces an unprecedented financial crisis.

title: Government Reviewer of Bolton Book Describes Unprecedented White House Intervention
summary: Official who examined former Trump adviser's book for classified information said administration lawyers pressed her to sign misleading statements. WASHINGTON-The government official assigned to examine whether former national security adviser John Bolton's book contains classified information said Trump administration lawyers asked her to sign misleading statements about her review, adding fuel to Mr. Bolton's claims that he was targeted for his unflattering portrait of President Trump.

title: Evans Says He Supports Fed's Low-Rate Guidance
summary: The central bank's policy is set appropriately for the challenges facing the nation, according to Chicago Fed President Charles Evans. title: How to Make a Really Beautiful Rice Bowl
summary: Tomato and saffron in the recipe give the rice its red hue. Fava beans, a flurry of dill and a drizzle of yogurt provide striking (and delicious) contrast.. title: Are College Reopenings Fueling Covid-19's Spread?
summary: Schools that reopened for face-to-face classes might have caused tens of thousands of additional coronavirus cases recently, a study has found. Colleges and universities that reopened for in-person classes might have significantly fueled the spread of Covid-19 in recent weeks, according to a new study conducted by researchers at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro, Indiana University, the University of Washington and Davidson College.

title: 'The Schubert Generation' Review: A Great Composer Gets His Due
summary: A 'Now Hear This' episode on PBS focuses on the prolific Franz Schubert and features extraordinary performances of his work.. To which the correct answer was, "Because he's Beethoven." But among the things we learn from "The Schubert Generation" on PBS is that even Franz Schubert was in awe of Ludwig van Beethoven. Also, that Franz Schubert deserves much more attention.

summary: With its mini meatballs and itsy-bitsy pasta, Italian wedding soup is designed to delight. Add some hearty greens, and you have an irresistible fall meal.. summary: Nation's murder rate remained at highest level in decades despite fall in number of killings. summary: Why would millions want to immigrate if the U.S. is a land of 'systemic racism'?. The left keeps saying America is systemically racist and President Trump is a white supremacist. So why do so many black Africans want to immigrate?

title: Before Reporting Became 'Journalism'
summary: Writers subdued their egos and encouraged readers to think. Nowadays it's all about arousing emotion.. My father's favorite word of dismissal was "phony." As a young man, he worked for the Philadelphia Inquirer. For him and his fellow reporters, phony was the watchword-an instinct. That period-the late 1930s, going into the war-had the atmosphere of a movie by Frank Capra, who was big on newspaper reporters as everyman types. After the calamitous sucker-punch of the Great Depression, a guy didn't want to be a sap.

title: How to Play Online Poker Without Being a Jerk
summary: A seasoned card player offers 5 tips on seamlessly moving your regular game night online-and resisting the urge to cuss your closest friends. ONE UPSIDE to spending so much time at home in 2020 is that it's inspired us to try new things: Beer yoga, whittling, talking to your spouse. For me, online poker is the revelation of the year. I'm not new to the game, but thanks to Zoom and the PokerStars app, I no longer spend 45 minutes stuck in traffic to play poker with my friends, then another 45 driving back while cursing my last hand. But online games can bring out some brutish behavior. Here, pointers on playing nicely.

title: United Wholesale Mortgage Goes Public in Biggest SPAC Deal Ever
summary: Merger with Gores SPAC will take the lender public at valuation above $16 billion. The biggest wholesale mortgage originator in the U.S. is merging with a special-purpose acquisition company in a deal that will take the lender public at a valuation north of $16 billion, the record for a type of deal that has become all the rage on Wall Street.

title: Belarus Leader Alexander Lukashenko Holds Surprise Inauguration
summary: President reclaims office with low-key ceremony after claiming victory in disputed election. MOSCOW-Belarus President Alexander Lukashenko was sworn in for a sixth term in a surprise inauguration ceremony, catching his opponents off guard and depriving them of an opportunity to stage another mass protest against the handling of last month's election.

title: Medicare Won't Cover Costs for Emergency Virus Vaccine
summary: Trump administration officials are exploring options to quickly fix plan to make the vaccine free for all Americans. Medicare wouldn't cover the cost of administering any coronavirus vaccine approved for emergency use, leaving Trump administration officials exploring options to quickly fix the government's plan to make the vaccine free for all Americans.

title: U.S. Economy Continues Steady Recovery in September, Surveys Show
summary: Faltering services sector separately weighs on Europe and Asia. The U.S. economy in September continued its steady recovery from the sharp declines in the second quarter as demand and output strengthened, according to new business surveys. But the pace faltered in Europe and Asia, where new infections have led to new restrictions on activity.

title: Six TV Shows to Watch Now That Will Satisfy the Travel Itch
summary: 'Unorthodox' co-creator writer Anna Winger and other notables on the TV series they find most addictively transporting. "In 'Beforeigners' (HBO Max), a seasoned cop in Oslo pairs up with a rookie from the Middle Ages-it's part 'Lethal Weapon,' part 'Alien Nation.' 'Unorthodox' ( Netflix ), about a woman fleeing an arranged marriage in Williamsburg's Hasidic community for a new life in Berlin, shirks Lifetime movie trappings. 'Giri/Haji' (Netflix) is an amalgam of gangster movies and hyper-real manga where a Japanese detective scours the London underworld to find his brother. I love that these series are so specific in culture but universal in story.

title: Gale Sayers, Bears Hall of Fame Running Back, Dies at 77
summary: Featured in the movie 'Brian's Song' for his friendship with cancer-stricken teammate, he later became a stockbroker and philanthropist. He was 77.

title: Coronavirus Poses an Array of New Legal Risks for Companies
summary: Remote work, new suppliers, complex government regulations and travel restrictions all create potential legal perils during the pandemic. The coronavirus pandemic has created a legal minefield for companies.

title: How Companies Can Create an Ethics Program for a New Era
summary: It used to be that companies just had to make sure they didn't break the law to be considered ethical. Now, it's so much more than that. For many years, business ethics and legal compliance were held to be one and the same. As long as a business didn't break a law, its only real ethical imperative was doing the best for its shareholders. End of story.

title: New York Subway Cars to Return to Service After Safety Review
summary: A report, to be presented to MTA board members, concludes that known safety issues with the Bombardier cars have been resolved. New York City's newest subway cars are expected to return to service this week after transit officials pulled them for a safety review in June when two cars decoupled while a train was moving.

title: Figure Skating Turns to Virtual Competition as a Covid-19 Fallback
summary: U.S. skaters are competing head-to-head by recording their performances and sending them to a remote judging panel. Then he had to quickly upload the recording to his sport's governing body.

title: One Senator's Strategy for Containing Chinese Tech Dominance
summary: Democrat Mark Warner, a former telecom executive, suggests industrial policy may be necessary to sustain Western competition to China. When Mark Warner was in the telecommunications business in the 1980s and 1990s, he didn't think much about how U.S. rules and standards shaped the global use of technology-it was a given. "I never appreciated how much we set the standards on almost every technology and innovation, even if not invented in America," Mr. Warner said in an interview this week. "We flooded the zone with engineers. We had the best schools, we had most of the companies. It got built in as an assumed advantage, and we kind of got lazy about it."

title: Why Some Classic Films Still Aren't Streaming, From 'Jungle Fever' to 'Silkwood'
summary: Resume Subscription. Want to stream "Silkwood" on demand tonight-the 1983 drama that stars Meryl Streep and was nominated for five Oscars? Sorry, that isn't possible. How about John Huston's "Prizzi's Honor," or "Bamboozled" by Spike Lee? Good luck.

title: U.S. Drops Case Against Chinese Scientist at UVA
summary: Hu Haizhou, who was studying underwater robotics, had permission to access code he allegedly stole. Prosecutors abruptly moved to drop criminal charges against a visiting Chinese scientist at the University of Virginia who had been arrested last month on allegations of stealing trade secrets from his professor, after the university acknowledged the scientist was authorized to access some of the material.

title: Saudi Arabia to Resume Religious Tourism in Bid to Revive Economy
summary: Kingdom is set to reopen the main mosques in Mecca and Medina, the holiest sites in Islam. Saudi Arabia plans to reopen the two holiest sites in Islam to pilgrims in October, seven months after it suspended visits to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, as it attempts to revive its floundering economy.

title: Some Covid-19 Patients Show Signs of Heart Damage Months Later
summary: Recent research suggests some people who recovered might have lingering heart inflammation and injury, even if their cases weren't severe. The new coronavirus can leave some patients with signs of heart inflammation and injury months after they get sick with Covid-19, even in cases where their illness wasn't severe, researchers say.

title: Tesla Drops, Nike Surges: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Tesla's Battery Day failed to impress investors, who sent the stock sliding lower in premarket trading.. Here's what we are watching as markets kick into gear Wednesday.

title: Supreme Court Plays Bigger Campaign Role for Trump Than Biden
summary: President readies to name his choice for seat opened by the death of Justice Ginsburg, while Democrat focuses more on health care. WASHINGTON-President Trump has polled supporters on whether he should nominate a woman to the Supreme Court and some waved signs at recent campaign rallies reading "Fill That Seat."

title: Refinancing Your Mortgage Is About to Get More Expensive
summary: Higher costs lurk even before the adverse market fee kicks in on Dec. 1. Here's how to play it smart.. Amid historically low rates, refinancing is hot-though it got doused with some cold water on Aug. 12, when the Federal Housing Finance Agency announced a significant new fee: All refinances backed by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac , which the FHFA oversees, would be subject to the Adverse Market Refinance Fee, equivalent to 0.5% of the total loan amount, starting Sept. 1. The fee is intended to help cover at least $6 billion of projected losses incurred by the Covid-19 crisis, the FHFA said in an August statement. Two weeks after the initial announcement, after an outcry from the mortgage industry, the FHFA revised its previous deadline, pronouncing that the start date for the fee would be Dec. 1.

title: The 11 Best Books of Fall
summary: From stories by familiar faces like Margaret Atwood and Don DeLillo to bizarre, one-of-a-kind tales of sentient, stuffed hedgehogs, WSJ. picks the best books of the coming season. This fall, a number of familiar authors are serving up twists. Margaret Atwood is following up her Booker Prize-winning novel The Testaments with a book of poetry, Don DeLillo is writing not about politics, economics or terrorism but about Super Bowl Sunday (and digital, global apocalypse) and Nicole Krauss, known for her intense, complex novels, is releasing her first collection of short stories. Some less-familiar writers have anticipated books as well, like David Diop, a French-Senegalese academic and novelist, whose novel about a Senegalese soldier fighting for France in the First World War has been translated into English. Japanese writer Sayaka Murata also appears in translation, spinning a fantastical tale about an 11-year-old girl and her stuffed hedgehog, who she believes has come from another planet. Here are WSJ.'s picks for autumn's best books.

title: Lagoa Would Bring an Atypical Background to the Supreme Court
summary: Not well-connected in Washington and New York law circles, the child of Cuban exiles has spent most of her career in Florida. Barbara Lagoa, a Cuban-American who spent the bulk of her judicial career in Florida's state courts, has emerged as a leading potential U.S. Supreme Court pick who could mobilize voters in a key battleground state.

title: Peak Oil Is Already Shifting Markets
summary: Prospect of falling demand for crude could unleash a long-term scramble between rival producer nations. After decades of relative maturity, the oil market might be about to enter a second childhood.

title: Covid-19 Is Making SAT, ACT Harder to Take
summary: Exams canceled for many students seeking to take them, leaving some to travel hours to find open sites. Jeb Bartholomew, a high-school senior from Weston, Mass., started studying for the ACT in February, planning to take it two months later. His test date was canceled. Then again. And two more times.

title: Notre Dame Postpones Game, the Latest Virus Disruption for ACC Football
summary: Coronavirus disruptions have altered four games and paused practices at 10 schools, including Notre Dame, which temporarily joined the conference for 2020. The football season in the Atlantic Coast Conference is just 10 days old and already under heavy pressure from a blitzing opponent: the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Cindy McCain Formally Endorses Biden
summary: 'We are Republicans, yes, but Americans foremost,' said the wife of the late GOP Sen. John McCain. Cindy McCain, the wife of the late GOP Sen. John McCain of Arizona who was a frequent critic of President Trump, officially endorsed Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden Tuesday night.

title: Stock Exchanges Present Opportunity as Volumes Surge
summary: Shares of American exchange operators have mostly performed well this year, especially compared with other financials. Stocks might be very expensive right now. But stock exchanges aren't.

title: Time, Energy and Bat Guano: A New Exhibit of Overlooked Connections
summary: Artists Allora & Calzadilla open an exhibition at Houston's Menil Collection. A sprawling tree made of compressed coal. A cargo-boat engine cast from bat guano, a natural fertilizer. A 70-foot-long canvas speckled with iron filings set by a jolt of electricity.

title: Bullwhip Effect Could Boost U.S. Economy
summary: Businesses that ran down inventories when Covid-19 arrived are now trying to build them back up, creating a powerful boost investors shouldn't ignore. Businesses that ran down their inventories when the Covid-19 crisis struck are now trying to build them back up. That is creating a powerful boost that, while temporary in nature, investors shouldn't ignore.

title: European Army Plans Face Battlefield Reality in Africa
summary: French president's push to cut military reliance on U.S., scorned by Trump, struggles in Sahel. BRUSSELS-In a troubled part of West Africa, Europe is fielding a military force intended to show it can handle its own security and reduce its reliance on the U.S.

title: Sneaker Platform Goat Group Raises $100 Million to Fund Expansion Plans
summary: New funding round values the company at $1.75 billion, according to a person familiar with the deal. Goat Group, best known for its online marketplace for sneakerheads, has raised $100 million in a Series E funding round to further its expansion into new apparel and product categories, as well as its efforts to work with more brands to sell their products directly on its platform.

title: Johnson & Johnson Begins Final-Stage Testing of Covid-19 Vaccine
summary: Four experimental coronavirus shots have now entered Phase 3 testing in the U.S.. Johnson & Johnson said Wednesday it started a 60,000-person clinical trial of its single-dose Covid-19 vaccine on three continents, becoming the fourth experimental Covid-19 shot to enter final-stage testing in the U.S.

title: Alexei Navalny Leaves Hospital After Treatment for Poisoning
summary: Russian opposition leader says he will focus on recovery from exposure to nerve agent Novichok. Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny has been discharged from a Berlin hospital after being treated for what scientists said was exposure to the nerve agent Novichok.

title: Fracker Extraction Oil Greased the Political Skids in Colorado
summary: Before filing for bankruptcy, company spent millions to influence local regulations affecting its business. In the two years before it went bankrupt in June, Extraction Oil & Gas Inc. funneled more than $10 million into political donations, most of it aimed at quashing a movement that threatened its business of forcing oil and gas out of the Colorado bedrock.

title: Dunkin', Stadiums Try Checkout-Free Shopping as Social Distancing Remains a Priority
summary: Checkout-free technology comes with behavioral barriers for customers-and financial uncertainty for retailers. Coffee chain Dunkin' and hospitality stands at sports stadiums are testing a new checkout-free payment system from Mastercard Inc. as retailers try to meet shoppers' desire for speed and reduced human contact.

title: ViacomCBS Stays All In on Showtime
summary: Premium network to remain a stand-alone streaming service, rather than be part of new Paramount+. When ViacomCBS Inc. unveiled plans last week to launch Paramount+, a supersize streaming service featuring content from across the media company's myriad units, something was missing: Showtime.

title: CME, Nasdaq to Launch Water Futures Contract
summary: Market will be first of its kind for world's most crucial commodity, organizers say. Farmers are known to pray for rain. Now they can hedge against unanswered invocations.

title: New Tech Chief of Startup Hypergiant Envisions Closer Human-AI Collaboration
summary: Mohammed Farooq previously served as a general manager in IBM's Global Technology Services unit. Hypergiant Industries Inc. tapped a former International Business Machines Corp. official as its first chief technology officer, the artificial intelligence startup announced Tuesday.

title: Streaming TV Is Surging, but the Ads Remain on Repeat
summary: Measurement problems are holding back advertising in connected TV, ad buyers say. People are streaming more movies and shows on internet-connected TV sets. But keeping track of who is watching what and where-and how many times they see the same ads-is becoming a bigger frustration for advertisers seeking to move money into the medium.

title: What CEOs Really Think About Remote Work
summary: Most Popular News. CEOs and other executives say they've seen enough to judge whether remote work is working. But the verdict depends on whom you ask.

title: Volkswagen Trucking Business Invests in Self-Driving Truck Developer TuSimple
summary: The companies say they will work together on bringing automation to the Traton Group's European freight-hauling brands. Volkswagen AG trucking subsidiary Traton Group will work with automation startup TuSimple to develop self-driving trucks and will take a stake in the technology company as part of their agreement.

title: Musk Promises $25,000 Tesla Using Cheaper Batteries
summary: Company has eventual annual production target of 20 million vehicles, potentially becoming world's largest auto maker. Elon Musk laid out a plan for Tesla Inc. to build a cheap electric car using drastically lower-cost batteries to make a $25,000 vehicle and potentially turn the company into the world's largest auto maker.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Trump's Supreme Court Pick: How President Plans to Fill Ginsburg's Seat
summary: Q&A on past election-year vacancies; judges on the shortlist; hurdles to a confirmation. President Trump says he will nominate a woman this weekend to succeed Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, despite opposition from Democrats who say the selection should wait until after the November election. Here are answers to questions about the Supreme Court nominating process following the death of Justice Ginsburg.

title: Why Finance Executives Choose SPACs: A Guide to the IPO Rival
summary: Companies are using special-purpose acquisition companies to gain a public listing. Executives increasingly are using an alternative to IPOs to take their companies public, choosing to sell to what is known as a special-purpose acquisition company to attract new investors and potentially cut down on the time it takes to reach public markets.

title: Nike's Quick Rebound Could Lead to Sprains
summary: While there is much to be excited about, keeping up with a soaring valuation could prove difficult. Nike has made an impressive rebound.

title: Draft Guidelines Say Covid-19 Vaccine to Require Strict Review
summary: U.S. Food and Drug Administration submitted the proposed guidelines for authorizing emergency use of a Covid-19 vaccine to White House and Health and Human Services Department for review. U.S. health regulators have drafted guidelines that would require a Covid-19 vaccine to meet rigorous standards to gain a speedy clearance for use, according to people familiar with the matter, an effort to ensure the shots work safely before they are widely distributed.

title: House Passes Short-Term Spending Bill to Keep Government Funded Through Dec. 11
summary: Senate expected to vote on the measure this week. WASHINGTON-The House Tuesday night passed a short-term spending bill keeping the government funded through Dec. 11, after Democrats reached a deal with the White House over farm aid and food assistance.

title: Florida Asphalt Company Agrees to Pay $16.6 Million to Resolve Bribery Case
summary: Prosecutors say Sargeant Marine Inc. and affiliates paid bribes to win contracts from state-controlled companies in Brazil, Venezuela and Ecuador. A Florida asphalt company pleaded guilty and agreed to pay $16.6 million to resolve charges stemming from a foreign bribery probe spanning three South American countries.

title: GOP Senators Target Supreme Court Confirmation by Election Day
summary: Republicans back speedy schedule aimed at filling vacancy before Nov. 3; president says he will announce nominee at 5 p.m. on Saturday. WASHINGTON-More Republicans are pushing to get a successor to Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg confirmed by the November elections, after senators dashed Democrats' efforts to stop President Trump from moving ahead with a nominee.

title: Palantir Projects Full-Year Revenue to Surpass $1 Billion
summary: One of Silicon Valley's oldest private startups also expects third-quarter revenue to rise about 47%. Palantir Technologies Inc. expects revenue to top $1 billion this year, as the company unveils its outlook ahead of its long-anticipated stock listing following decades of teasing the market with plans to go public.

title: Plea Entered for Woman Accused of Mailing Poison to White House
summary: Pascale Cecile Veronique Ferrier was arrested Sunday at the U.S.-Canada border in Buffalo. N.Y.; judge orders she remain detained. A Canadian woman accused of mailing ricin to the White House last week appeared before a federal magistrate judge in Buffalo, N.Y., Tuesday afternoon to face a charge of making threats against President Trump.
